Introduction to wtlike

This package, available on PyPI as "wtlike", is an independent implementation applying the Kerr weighted likelihood to Fermi photon data.

Differences

There are some important extensions to the computation model he assumes, and implements in his godot package:

  • Weights and photon data are separate
    • godot: Run the full gtlike analysis, including the diffuse and nearby sources for the ROI containing the source; then use this model for the full data set to calculate a weight for each photon based on its energy, position, and event type.
    • wtlike: Perform the above using only the binned data, then save the weights in a table allowing lookup for individual photons at a later time, perhaps on data collected after the table creation. That is, the data can be, within a few minutes. brought up to the most recent GSFC release.

  • Photons and livetime info for any direction are taken from a compact version of the full FT1/FT2 set of files.
    This makes the system very portable, with <3GB needed, with no need for the full fermipy package, and much faster to start a source, and especially to rebin an existing light curve.

  • Using a Poisson-like representation of the likeliihood.
    It turns out that any likelihood evaluated with the Kerr formula, involving a lot of computation, can be safely approximated with a 3-parameter scaled Poisson function.

  • Exposure is calculated based on the energy and event type, rather than assuming a power-law.
    For count flux measuments, which are dominated by the lowest energies, this does not matter much, but it allows measurment of energy dependence, a future enhancement.

The user interface

wtlike is designed for, (but does not require) Jupyterlab notebooks, that is, to enhance interactivity. As this presentation shows, a basic light curve, can be done with a single line of code:

WtLike('4C 28.07').plot()

If the source in question is already in the cache managed by wtlike, requires 2s. Creating different views, with restricted time ranges or intervals, is simply done with the view() member fuction. Running a Bayesian Block analysis is performed with the function bb_view().

{% raw %} 
def lcr_about():
    """
    ### The Light Curve Repository "about" example

    I'll use this strong, active source as an example for a simple comparison.
    Here is the 4FGL source 4FGL J0237.8+2848 (associated with 4C 28.07), as shown on its ["about" page](https://fermi.gsfc.nasa.gov/ssc/data/access/lat/LightCurveRepository/about.html)

    {img}

    This shows 3-day bins through Sep 28 2020. 
    """
    img=image('LCR_about_fig2.png', caption=None)
    return locals()

nbdoc(lcr_about)

The Light Curve Repository "about" example

I'll use this strong, active source as an example for a simple comparison. Here is the 4FGL source 4FGL J0237.8+2848 (associated with 4C 28.07), as shown on its "about" page

This shows 3-day bins through Sep 28 2020.

{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
def lcr_about_example():
    """
    This is wtlike version {__version__}.
    
    ### Set up the source
    
    The key code statement is 
    ```
    wtl = WtLike('4FGL J0237.8+2848', time_bins=(0,0,3))
    ```
    
    This instantiates the class `WtLike`, specifying a source name, and 3-day (default is 7) time bins for the full data set.
    The name can be that of any source known to `astropy` which corresponds, to within $0.1^\circ$, to a 4FGL source,
    *e.g.* 4C 28.07 in this case.
    Then
    `wtl.plot()` is all that is needed to make the plot. 
    {print1}
    {fig1}
    
    ### Apply Bayesian blocks 
    To partion the 3-day cells using Bayesin Blocks needs another function member of the class `WtLike`. The 
    statement `bb = bb_view()` runs the analsyis on the current 3-day binning, and returns a new instance of `WtLike`.
    This instance implements `bb_plot()`, to make an overlay showing the BB partitions, each with a new fit. 
    {print2}
    {fig2}
    
    ### Look at the last month, daily bins
    {print3}
    {fig3}
    """
    from wtlike import __version__
    with capture('Loading data output') as print1:
        with Timer() as t:
            wtl = WtLike('4FGL J0237.8+2848', time_bins=(0,0,3))
        print(f'Elapsed time: {t.elapsed/60:.1f} min')
    fig1 = wtl.plot(UTC=True,figsize=(15,4), fignum=1)
    
    with capture('Bayesian block analysis output') as print2:
        with Timer() as t:
            bb = wtl.bb_view()
        print(f'Elapsed time: {t.elapsed/60:.1f} min')
    fig2= bb.plot(UTC=True,figsize=(15,4), fignum=2);
    
    with capture('Rebining output') as print3:
        recent = wtl.view(-30,0,1)
    fig3=recent.plot(tzero=round(wtl.stop), fignum=3);
        
    return locals()
    
nbdoc(lcr_about_example)

This is wtlike version 0.3.9

Set up the source

The key call here is

wtl = WtLike('4FGL J0237.8+2848', time_bins=(0,0,3))

This instantiates the class WtLike, specifing a source name, and 3-day (default is 7) time bins for the full data set. The name can be that of any source known to astropy witch corresponds, to within $0.1^\circ$, to a 4FGL source, e.g. 4C 28.07 in this case. Then wtl.plot() is all that is needed to make the plot.

Loading data output 
SourceData:  4FGL J0237.8+2848: Restoring from cache with key "P88Y0643_data"
SourceData: Source 4FGL J0237.8+2848 with:
   data:       123,321 photons from 2008-08-04 to 2021-08-28
   exposure: 3,194,310 intervals,  average effective area 2509 cm^2 for 95.5 Ms
    rates:  source 1.43e-07/s, background 3.71e-07/s, S/N ratio 3.85e-01
CellData: Bin photon data into 1590 3-day bins from 54683.0 to 59453.0
LightCurve: select 1545 cells for fitting with e>15 & n>2
Elapsed time: 0.1 min

Apply Bayesian blocks

To partion the 3-day cells using Bayesin Blocks needs another function member of the class WtLike. The statement bb = bb_view() runs the analsyis on the current 3-day binning, and returns a new instance of WtLike. This instance implements bb_plot(), to make an overlay showing the BB partitions, each with a new fit.

Bayesian block analysis output 
Bayesian Blocks: partitioning 1545 cells using LikelihoodFitness with penalty 5%
  found 80 / 1545 blocks.
LightCurve: Loaded 80 / 80 cells for fitting
Elapsed time: 0.6 min

Look at the last month, daily bins

Rebining output 
CellData: Bin photon data into 30 1-day bins from 59424.0 to 59454.0
LightCurve: select 30 cells for fitting with e>5 & n>2

{% endraw %}

What is missing

As pointed out in the LCR about page, there are "15 other variable sources within a 12 deg radius". Actually, another source has to be within a few degrees at most to have an impact. The Kerr scheme assumes that the background is constant, at most allowing for an overall rescaling
